title: Home loan inquiry won't find anything new
text:
The government has had the commission’s report, Competition in the Australian Financial System, since August last year but so far has implemented only a few of the 34 recommendations, such as the consumer data right to make it easier for customers to switch banks under the new open banking regime.

Dr King said there had already been a “lot of inquiries and there’s been lots of recommendations” from the commission, the ACCC’s December 2018 report on mortgages and the banking royal commission.

“I would be very surprised if the new ACCC inquiry finds any significant new information,” he said.

After his calls for the banks to pass on Reserve Bank of Australia rate cuts in full were ignored for a third time this year, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg told the ACCC on Monday to look into the pricing of residential mortgage products and to examine obstacles that stop customers switching lenders.

Make ACCC competition champ

Dr King said adopting the commission's recommendation to make the ACCC a permanent member of the Council of Financial Regulators would help promote competition against other regulators more concerned about the financial system not blowing up.

He cited the example of the prudential regulator restricting the amount of interest-only loans to slow down the hot property market a few years ago, which the ACCC found let the big banks lift their profits by an extra $1.1 billion.

“The problem is on one regulatory side you want competition and the other regulatory side wants safety and they don’t really go together,” Dr King said.

Advertisement

“There isn’t a competition champion at the financial regulators table and that’s why we recommended we need the ACCC on the Council of Financial Regulators.”

The council is chaired by the Reserve Bank of Australia and its members include Treasury, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.

ACCC boss Rod Sims has been invited to the occasional council quarterly meeting, but other regulators have privately rejected a push for the competition watchdog to be made a permanent member.

Online calculator due next year

An online calculator recommended by the Productivity Commission would allow consumers to more easily compare home loan rates across about 4000 mortgage products and get comparisons to borrowers in different postcodes.

“Given the regulators have the data on actual home loans written and interest rates, making that available so customers can compare across suburbs would help,” Dr King said.

ASIC deputy chairman Karen Chester said on Tuesday not all borrowers were paying the standard variable rate and “it’s very difficult for consumers to identify what rate they’re really paying compared to what’s being offered to somebody who is a new customer”.

It is understood financial regulators are progressing the online tool, and APRA, ASIC and Treasury are in discussions to try to have it up and running by next year.

Advertisement

Dr King said the big banks controlled about 75 per cent to 80 per cent of mortgages.

He rejected arguments from bankers that competition was robust among the big four and from emerging fintech lenders, saying the highly regulated banks did not face major threats like other industries.

“Macquarie and smaller retail banks are still relatively small and struggled to make inroads into the major banks,” Dr King said.

He lamented that the 2008 global financial crisis enabled big banks to take over regional banks, such as Commonwealth Bank’s acquisition of Bankwest and Westpac’s earlier takeover of St George, Bank of Melbourne and BankSA.

Dr King said mortgage brokers used to be a larger source of competition before the financial crisis, which caused a cheap source of funding, known as securitisation, to dry up.

“The securitisation market has not recovered to the same level and some of APRA’s rules have made it difficult for banks to establish ‘warehouses’ to put their money behind the securitisers.”

Brokers now work for the banks

He cited Commonwealth Bank buying mortgage broker Aussie Home Loans and Westpac acquiring RAMS Home Loans.

Advertisement

“The broker channel, which is critically important to consumers and accounts for more than 50 per cent of mortgages, is not operating to promote competition in the way it once was,” Dr King said.

“Instead of being independent brokers acting on the consumer's behalf, some of them now are unfortunately channels for the big banks and their products.

“It needs to be made clearer who is behind the loans.”

Rather than breaking up the big banks, Dr King said the government should implement the commission’s recommendation to eradicate conflicts of interest in mortgage broking and banking.

“The broker is still being paid to keep the customer in the old product even if it’s not in the customer’s best interest.”

Before the May election, Mr Frydenberg caved in to lobbying from brokers to backflip on the royal commission’s recommendation to ban upfront and trailing commissions paid by banks to brokers who sign up new home loan customers.

Dr King said he agreed with the government’s decision to reject commissioner Kenneth Hayne’s recommendation to ban upfront commissions, a potential change that would have forced customers to pay thousands of dollars out of their own pockets to receive advice from a broker.

Advertisement

Dr King said the best-interest duty that applies to financial planners should not only be expanded to brokers – as the government is preparing to do – but apply to bankers writing home loans.

“Banks need to be obliged to act in their consumers’ best interests when they’re writing mortgages,” he said.

Mr Frydenberg said the government was taking action on the Productivity Commission report in concert with its response to the royal commission.

“The government continues to implement and examine ways to increase competition across the banking and financial industry.”

“We’re also rolling out the consumer data right to give consumers greater access to their personal information allowing them to securely transfer their banking data to other providers to get a better deal.”

“Giving consumers more power is what makes markets more competitive; giving them more information, giving them access to their own data, and giving them the chance to go out and get the lowest possible price on their borrowings.”

Former Productivity Commission chairman Peter Harris last week urged the government to boost home loan competition by creating a tough “best interest duty” for brokers and bankers so loyal customers don’t get ripped off.
description: The problems in the mortgage market are well known and the latest ACCC inquiry make any new discoveries, says the Productivity Commission's Stephen King.
